Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Synergy: Cyber Enabled Manufacturing Systems (CeMs) for Small Lot Manufacture

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides funding for the development of Cyber Enabled Manufacturing (CeMs) process control for small lot manufacturing that incorporates a model of the process directly into the control algorithm. Such a model can be used to accommodate changes in the physical product and the manufacturing process and thus the manufacturing monitoring and control algorithm, so that changing conditions are easily accommodated without extensive additional experiments. A set of objectives of this physics and cyber-enabled manufacturing process control system are rational setting of manufacturing tolerances, real time prediction of manufacturing defects, real time control of process to eliminate defects, and real time monitoring and control for small lot manufacturing. The methodologies we propose to achieve these goals are high fidelity, physics based models including models of faults/defects, uncertainty quantification, reduced order models that run in real time, measurement, real time prediction, real time computer architecture, real time control with inverse solutions, and automating the CeMs process for generic manufacturing processes

If successful, the results of this research will greatly reduce cycle time in producing new or modified products and improve the quality of manufacturing processes with accompanying reduction in waste, energy use, and cost. The development of such accurate control algorithms and their application to manufacturing processes can provide a competitive edge to US manufacturers. Perhaps more importantly, the education of engineers involved this research will supply US industry with employees who can apply this technology to many industrial processes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
It is becoming increasingly understood that manufacturing is of fundamental importance to the vitality of the United States economy and National security. It has also become increasingly obvious that the entertainment industry of books, movies and music has been revolutionized by the ability of the online industry to deliver small quantities of varied products at essentially the same price as large quantities of identical products.  This has resulted in consumers selecting and buying across many more products i.e. different books, movies and songs rather than just the “top-sellers” and the “hits”. This has only come about because the cost of production of small lots of these entertainment products has become comparable to large lots. The Internet made this possible since the product can be totally digitized and substantially resides in the cyber world.

It is our long-range goal to repeat this small lot revolution for physical products by substantially reducing the cost of manufacturing small lots of physical objects. Although complete parity between the cost of small and large lots in the physical world is a difficult goal to achieve, even a small but significant step in this direction would open up fundamentally new business for U.S. manufacturers. The contribution of this work is the development of a framework and the methods for cyber enabled manufacturing (CeMs) process control for small lot manufacturing. CeMs combines the power of modern high-fidelity physics based models, uncertainty quantification, real time computer architecture, estimation and control techniques. New techniques in each of these areas should evolve from the research. CeMs will robustly handle changes in process conditions, materials, and other variables without extensive empirical statistical testing to produce high quality products. The framework provides a quantum change for new and improved manufacturing process control for many industrial processes.

While addressing this goal, we educated engineers that are supplying US industry with employees who can apply this technology to manufacturing processes. As part of this program, we also actively recruited summer high school students who worked in our research team and we also actively recruited women researchers into the program.
